content:
This thread may be connected to the thread on the big Witt ring, but it's probably better to have it be a separate thread.

The free λ\lambdaλ-ring on one generator, Λ\LambdaΛ, is also known as the ring of symmetric functions. I will explain its real significance in a minute. It has various important elements:

  • the exterior power elements λi\lambda^iλi
  • the symmetric power elements σi\sigma^iσi
  • the Adams operations ψi\psi^iψi

The first two sequences of elements can be nicely understood using 2-rigs. Given any object rrr in any 2-rig R\mathsf{R}R we can define its ith exterior power Λi(r)\Lambda^i(r)Λi(r) and ith symmetric power Si(r)S^i(r)Si(r), using the same constructions that work in the familiar case R=Vect\mathsf{R} = \mathsf{Vect}R=Vect. In particular we can do this in the free 2-rig on one generator xxx, which happens to be called kS‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}}kS for reasons I could explain. So, we get important objects

Λi(x),Si(x)∈kS‾ \Lambda^i(x), S^i(x) \in \overline{k\mathsf{S}}Λi(x),Si(x)∈kS

You can think of these as the 'walking' or 'generic' ith exterior power and ith symmetric power, respectively.

Now, the really important thing about Λ\LambdaΛ is that it's the [[Grothendieck group]] of the free 2-rig on one generator. Thus, we get elements

λi=[Λi(x)] \lambda^i = [\Lambda^i(x)] λi=[Λi(x)]
σi=[Si(x)] \sigma^i = [S^i(x)] σi=[Si(x)]

in Λ\LambdaΛ.

But the [[Adams operations]] ψi\psi^iψi cannot be defined as the equivalence classes of certain objects in kS‾\overline{k \mathsf{S}}kS. And that makes them more tantalizing.

They are formal differences of equivalence classes of objects in kS‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}}kS. For example:

ψ0=1\psi^0 = 1ψ0=1
ψ1=λ1\psi^1 = \lambda^1ψ1=λ1
ψ2=(λ1)2−2λ2\psi^2 = (\lambda^1)^2 - 2 \lambda^2ψ2=(λ1)2−2λ2

and so on. Notice that we're using exponents in two ways here: λ2\lambda^2λ2 is just the second exterior power element while (λ1)2(\lambda^1)^2(λ1)2 is the square of the first exterior power element, which we can define because Λ\LambdaΛ is a ring!

Why do we care about Adams operations? There are many reasons, but one is this.

As you probably know, you can apply a polynomial in Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] to any element of any ring. Why is this? Ultimately it's because Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] is the free ring on one generator, namely xxx. So, if we have any element rrr of any ring RRR, there's a unique ring homomorphism from Z[x]\mathbb{Z}[x]Z[x] to RRR sending xxx to rrr. And then this homomorphism sends any polynomial PPP to some element of RRR, which we call P(r)P(r)P(r). And this is how we apply a polynomial to an element of a ring!

So, the free ring on one generator acts on any ring. (Not as ring homomorphisms, mind you! I'm just saying any polynomial P∈Z[x]P \in \mathbb{Z}[x]P∈Z[x] acts to send elements r∈Rr \in Rr∈R to new elements P(r)∈RP(r) \in RP(r)∈R.)

This is a completely general trick. So, the free 2-rig on one generator acts on any 2-rig. Taking Grothendieck groups, we get a baby version of this fact: the free lambda-ring on one generator, Λ\LambdaΛ, acts on any lambda-ring.

Being the free lambda-ring on one generator, Λ\LambdaΛ acts on any lambda-ring.

So, the Adams operations ψi∈Λ\psi^i \in \Lambdaψi∈Λ, whatever they are, act to give maps from any lambda-ring RRR to itself! And these maps have a remarkable property: they are ring homomorphisms!

This is not true of the λi\lambda^iλi or the σi\sigma^iσi.

For example, the symmetric power operations act on vector spaces or indeed objects in any 2-rig, but they don't obey rules like

Si(V⊕W)≅Si(V)⊕Si(W)S^i(V \oplus W) \cong S^i(V) \oplus S^i(W)Si(V⊕W)≅Si(V)⊕Si(W)

so we don't expect that their avatars σi\sigma^iσi in Λ\LambdaΛ would act on lambda-rings in a way that obeys

σi(r+s)=σi(r)+σi(s)\sigma^i(r + s) = \sigma^i(r) + \sigma^i(s)σi(r+s)=σi(r)+σi(s)

and indeed they don't. For example we have

S2(V⊕W)=S2(V)⊕(V⊗W)⊕S2(W) S^2(V \oplus W) = S^2(V) \oplus (V \otimes W) \oplus S^2(W) S2(V⊕W)=S2(V)⊕(V⊗W)⊕S2(W)

when V,WV,WV,W are objects in any 2-rig, and this winds up giving

σ2(r+s)=σ2(r)+rs+σ2(s) \sigma^2(r+ s) = \sigma^2(r) + r s + \sigma^2(s) σ2(r+s)=σ2(r)+rs+σ2(s)

But the Adams operations behave mysteriously much better, e.g.

ψ2(r+s)=ψ2(r)+ψ2(s)\psi^2(r + s) = \psi^2(r) + \psi^2(s)ψ2(r+s)=ψ2(r)+ψ2(s)

SO: the definition of the Adams operations ψi\psi^iψi is more mysterious than that of the the λi\lambda^iλi and σi\sigma^iσi (which descend from familiar operations we do to vector spaces, vector bundles, group representations and objects of other 2-rigs). But their behavior is much nicer.

And this presents a puzzle: what's the best way to understand them, so that their definition is not mysterious, and their good behavior follows automatically from that?

Todd and I have been talking about that, and we have a guess. Roughly: while Adams operations don't arise from objects in the free 2-rig on one generator, they arise from the category of chain complexes of objects in the free 2-rig on one generator.

Or something like that: I'm being sloppy now, but we can get more precise, and we want to get completely precise about this.

I suppose I should say a preliminary word about how to define Adams operations! Here's one way. l'll say how the Adams operation ψi\psi^iψi acts on a lambda-ring. This description relies on some nontrivial theorems and at first seems to only cover a special case, but it has a conceptual clarity to it that some other more elementary descriptions lack (at least to me).

Say an element rrr of a lambda-ring RRR is at most n-dimensional if λi(r)=0\lambda^i(r) = 0λi(r)=0 for all i>n i \gt ni>n. I'll describe ψi(r)\psi^i(r)ψi(r) when rrr is at most nnn-dimensional for some nnn.

In Theorem 6.1, Atiyah and Tall prove the following version of the splitting principle:

Splitting Principle. Suppose the element rrr of the lambda-ring RRR is at most nnn-dimensional. Then RRR can be embedded in a lambda-ring R′R'R′ where

r=ℓ1+⋯+ℓn r = \ell_1 + \cdots + \ell_nr=ℓ1​+⋯+ℓn​

and each ℓi\ell_iℓi​ is at most 1-dimensional.

Then, we have

ψi(r)=ℓ1i+⋯+ℓni\psi^i(r) = \ell_1^i + \cdots + \ell_n^i ψi(r)=ℓ1i​+⋯+ℓni​

It's not obvious, but true, that:

1) ψi(r)\psi^i(r)ψi(r) is not only an element of R′R'R′ but actually of RRR
2) ψi(r)\psi^i(r)ψi(r) is independent of how we chose R′R'R′ and how we wrote rrr as a sum of elements that are at most 1-dimensional.
All this is somewhat miraculous!

If you believe these miracles then it's obvious that Adams operations get along with addition:

ψi(r+s)=ψi(r)+ψi(s)\psi^i(r + s) = \psi^i(r) + \psi^i(s) ψi(r+s)=ψi(r)+ψi(s)

at least if rrr and sss are both finite-dimensional (i.e., at most nnn-dimensional for some large enough nnn).

Simply write rrr and sss as sums of elements that are at most 1-dimensional; this also gives a way to write r+sr+sr+s as a sum of elements that are at most 1-dimensional, and then the formula for ψi\psi^iψi does the rest.

The same general style of argument shows

ψi(rs)=ψi(r)ψi(s)\psi^i(rs) = \psi^i(r) \psi^i(s)ψi(rs)=ψi(r)ψi(s)

at least when rrr and sss are finite-dimensional.

For this, we use splitting principle twice and write both rrr and sss as a sum of elements that are at most 1-dimensional, say:

r=ℓ1+⋯+ℓmr = \ell_1 + \cdots + \ell_m r=ℓ1​+⋯+ℓm​
s=ℓ1′+⋯+ℓn′ s = \ell'_1 + \cdots + \ell'_n s=ℓ1′​+⋯+ℓn′​

We thus have

rs=∑j=1m∑k=1nℓjℓk′ rs = \sum_{j = 1}^m \sum_{k = 1}^n \ell_j \ell'_k rs=∑j=1m​∑k=1n​ℓj​ℓk′​

Then we need to show that if two elements of a lambda-ring are at most 1-dimensional, then so is their product. This is an exercise using the definition of lambda-ring.

It follows that the above formula expresses rsrsrs as a sum of elements that are at most 1-dimensional!

Now we use the miraculous definition of ψi\psi^iψi three times. Remember, this definition says

r=ℓ1+⋯+ℓn  ⟹  ψi(r)=ℓ1i+⋯+ℓni r = \ell_1 + \cdots + \ell_n \implies \psi^i(r) = \ell_1^i + \cdots + \ell_n^i r=ℓ1​+⋯+ℓn​⟹ψi(r)=ℓ1i​+⋯+ℓni​

So, we have

ψi(r)=ℓ1i+⋯+ℓmi\psi^i(r) = \ell_1^i + \cdots + \ell_m^i ψi(r)=ℓ1i​+⋯+ℓmi​
ψi(s)=ℓ′1i+⋯+ℓ′ni \psi^i(s) = {\ell'}_1^i + \cdots + {\ell'}_n^i ψi(s)=ℓ′1i​+⋯+ℓ′ni​
ψi(rs)=∑j=1m∑k=1nℓjiℓ′ki \psi^i(rs) = \sum_{j = 1}^m \sum_{k = 1}^n \ell_j^i {\ell'}_k^i ψi(rs)=∑j=1m​∑k=1n​ℓji​ℓ′ki​

It follows that

ψi(rs)=ψi(r)ψi(s) \psi^i(rs) = \psi^i(r) \psi^i(s) ψi(rs)=ψi(r)ψi(s)

So, if every element of a lambda-ring RRR is finite-dimensional, each Adams operation

ψi:R→R \psi^i : R \to R ψi:R→R

is a ring homomorphism!

This is not quite optimal: in fact for every lambda-ring RRR, every Adams operation ψi:R→R\psi^i : R \to Rψi:R→R is a ring homomorphism. I only know how to show use this using a somewhat different argument. But the argument here seems more conceptual.

Let me wrap up by summarizing everything I just said. To make things terse, it helps to call an element of a lambda-ring that's at most 1-dimensional a subline.

Then the idea is this: to apply ψi\psi^iψi to a sum of sublines, we just take the ith power of each subline and then sum them up. It's then obvious that ψi\psi^iψi is additive, and since the product of sublines is a subline, we can also see ψi\psi^iψi is multiplicative.
Do you know how much of this story is coming from Adams operations simply being power operations and how much from them being power operations in a certain kind of setting, such as K-theory?

So there's also a way of defining Adams operations directly in terms of lambda-ring operations. One way of saying it is that their generating function ψt\psi_tψt​ is the logarithmic derivative of the generating function σt\sigma_tσt​ for the symmetric powers, shifted by degree 111:

∑n≥1ψntn=tddtlog⁡∑j≥0σjtj=tddt∑j≥0σjtj∑j≥0σjtj\sum_{n \geq 1}\psi^n t^n = t\frac{d}{dt} \log \sum_{j \geq 0} \sigma^j t^j = \frac{t\frac{d}{dt} \sum_{j \geq 0} \sigma^j t^j}{\sum_{j \geq 0} \sigma^j t^j}∑n≥1​ψntn=tdtd​log∑j≥0​σjtj=∑j≥0​σjtjtdtd​∑j≥0​σjtj​

If you accept the splitting principle as discussed in the Big Witt ring conversation, then as symmetric functions σj=σj(x1,x2,…)\sigma^j = \sigma^j(x_1, x_2, \ldots)σj=σj(x1​,x2​,…) in infinitely many variables x1,x2,…x_1, x_2, \ldotsx1​,x2​,…, we have

∑j≥0σjtj=∏i=1∞11−xit\sum_{j \geq 0} \sigma^j t^j = \prod_{i=1}^\infty \frac1{1 - x_i t}∑j≥0​σjtj=∏i=1∞​1−xi​t1​

and it is very easy to compute the logarithmic derivative of the product. It is

∑i=1∞xi1−xit\sum_{i = 1}^\infty \frac{x_i}{1 - x_i t}∑i=1∞​1−xi​txi​​

which when we multiply by ttt and expand the geometric series for xit1−xit\frac{x_i t}{1 - x_i t}1−xi​txi​t​, we get

∑n≥1(x1n+x2n+⋯ )tn\sum_{n \geq 1} (x_1^n + x_2^n + \cdots) t^n∑n≥1​(x1n​+x2n​+⋯)tn

which explains in another way how power sums arise via the splitting principle.

Also to be noted is the beautiful identity

1σt=λ−t\frac1{\sigma_t} = \lambda_{-t}σt​1​=λ−t​

which gives a convenient expression for the Adams operations in terms of the σi,λi\sigma^i, \lambda^iσi,λi:

ψt=tσt′λ−t=(∑j≥0jσjtj)⋅(∑k≥0(−1)kλktk)\psi_t = t \sigma_t' \lambda_{-t} = (\sum_{j \geq 0} j\sigma^j t^j) \cdot (\sum_{k \geq 0} (-1)^k \lambda^k t^k)ψt​=tσt′​λ−t​=(∑j≥0​jσjtj)⋅(∑k≥0​(−1)kλktk)

or ψn=∑k=0n(−1)k(n−k)σn−kλk\psi^n = \sum_{k=0}^n (-1)^k (n-k) \sigma^{n-k} \lambda^kψn=∑k=0n​(−1)k(n−k)σn−kλk.

David Corfield said:

Do you know how much of this story is coming from Adams operations simply being power operations and how much from them being power operations in a certain kind of setting, such as K-theory?

I don't know enough about power operations in general to answer this question yet. I know essentially nothing about them. So thanks: I have more to learn now!

But when you say "K-theory", don't think about K-theory of topological spaces, where we start with the 2-rig of vector bundles and take the Grothendieck group of that. That's historically all-important, but I'm saying here that Adams operations exist whenever you have a 2-rig and take the Grothendieck group of that. So they're fundamental to "categorified ring theory". And what Todd and I are doing is lifting them from the Grothendieck group to the 2-rig itself - or more precisely, another 2-rig built from that 2-rig, which includes a notion of "negative objects".

One thing to make explicit is that the additivity of the Adams operations,

ψt(r+s)=ψt(r)+ψt(s)\psi_t(r + s) = \psi_t(r) + \psi_t(s)ψt​(r+s)=ψt​(r)+ψt​(s),

is essentially equivalent to the exponential property of the σi\sigma^iσi,

σt(x+y)=σt(x)σt(y)\sigma_t(x + y) = \sigma_t(x) \sigma_t(y)σt​(x+y)=σt​(x)σt​(y)

because the logarithmic derivative takes products back to sums. One doesn't need to know what "log⁡\loglog" means particularly; the application σt(x)↦tσt′(x)σt(x)\sigma_t(x) \mapsto t\frac{\sigma_t'(x)}{\sigma_t(x)}σt​(x)↦tσt​(x)σt′​(x)​ takes products σt(x)σt(y)\sigma_t(x) \sigma_t(y)σt​(x)σt​(y) to sums just by the Leibniz rule.

Thanks for the terse review of the formulas defining Adams operations, @Todd Trimble! I think the meaning of many of these formulas will only be clear to people who are familiar with generating functions.

Starting with an easy one, there's this:

If you accept the splitting principle as discussed in the Big Witt ring conversation, then as symmetric functions σj=σj(x1,x2,…)\sigma^j = \sigma^j(x_1, x_2, \ldots)σj=σj(x1​,x2​,…) in infinitely many variables x1,x2,…x_1, x_2, \ldotsx1​,x2​,…, we have

∑j≥0σjtj=∏i=1∞11−xit\displaystyle{ \sum_{j \geq 0} \sigma^j t^j = \prod_{i=1}^\infty \frac1{1 - x_i t} }j≥0∑​σjtj=i=1∏∞​1−xi​t1​

If one mentally expands each geometric series

11−xit \displaystyle{ \frac1{1 - x_i t} }1−xi​t1​

and then multiplies them together, one sees that the coefficient of tjt^jtj is the sum of all monomials in the variables x1,x2,x3,…x_1, x_2, x_3, \dots x1​,x2​,x3​,… having total degree jjj, so

σj=∑p1+p2+⋯=jx1p1x2p2⋯ \displaystyle{ \sigma^j = \sum_{p_1 + p_2 + \cdots = j} x_1^{p_1} x_2^{p_2} \cdots }σj=p1​+p2​+⋯=j∑​x1p1​​x2p2​​⋯

This is a decategorified way of stating this fact:

If an object VVV in a 2-rig is a coproduct of sublines L1,L2,L3,…L_1, L_2, L_3, \dots L1​,L2​,L3​,…, then its jth symmetric power Sj(V)S^j(V)Sj(V) is the coproduct

Sj(V)≅⨁p1+p2+⋯=jL1⊗p1⊗L2⊗p2⊗⋯ \displaystyle{ S^j(V) \cong \bigoplus_{p_1 + p_2 + \cdots = j} L_1^{\otimes p_1} \otimes L_2^{\otimes p_2} \otimes \cdots } Sj(V)≅p1​+p2​+⋯=j⨁​L1⊗p1​​⊗L2⊗p2​​⊗⋯

The tensor product here makes sense because all but finitely many of the pip_ipi​ must be zero, and the zeroth tensor power of an object is the unit object for the tensor product, III.

But what is the categorified meaning of the quantity

σt=∑j≥0σjtj \displaystyle{ \sigma_t = \sum_{j \ge 0} \sigma^j t^j }σt​=j≥0∑​σjtj

in the first place? For example what's the meaning of ttt? I think Todd cracked the code, but let me report the answer.

Briefly, the symmetric algebra is a graded algebra, which we can split into homogeneous pieces or 'grades', and the exponent of ttt records the grade.

More formally:

For any 2-rig R\mathsf{R}R there's a 2-rig of N\mathbb{N}N-graded objects in R\mathsf{R}R. I will call this R[[t]]\mathsf{R}[[t]]R[[t]] because when we take its Grothendieck group we get

K(R[[t]])≅K(R)[[t]] K(\mathsf{R}[[t]]) \cong K(R)[[t]] K(R[[t]])≅K(R)[[t]]

where the ring at right consists of formal power series in K(R)K(R)K(R).

Why is this true? By definition, an N\mathbb{N}N-graded R\mathsf{R}R-object XXX is just a sequence of objects Xj∈RX_j \in \mathsf{R}Xj​∈R for j=0,1,2,…j = 0, 1, 2, \dotsj=0,1,2,…. Thus, passing to the Grothendieck group, we can write its equivalence class [X][X][X] as

∑j≥0[Xn]tj∈K(R)[[t]] \displaystyle{ \sum_{j \ge 0} [X_n] t^j \in K(R)[[t]] }j≥0∑​[Xn​]tj∈K(R)[[t]]

where the exponent of the formal variable ttt just keeps track of the grade.

So, it makes sense to call the 2-rig of N\mathbb{N}N-graded R\mathsf{R}R-objects R[[t]]\mathsf{R}[[t]]R[[t]].

In particular there's a symmetric algebra functor

S ⁣:R→R[[t]] S \colon \mathsf{R} \to \mathsf{R}[[t]]S:R→R[[t]]

sending any object V∈RV \in \mathsf{R}V∈R to its symmetric algebra S(V)S(V)S(V), which is the N\mathbb{N}N-graded R\mathsf{R}R-object whose jth grades is the jth symmetric powers Sj(V)S^j(V)Sj(V).

Using the power series notation, the equivalence class of S(V)S(V)S(V) in the Grothendieck group of R[[t]]\mathsf{R}[[t]]R[[t]] is

[S(V)]=∑j≥0[Sj(V)]tn \displaystyle{ [S(V)] = \sum_{j \ge 0} [S^j(V)] t^n } [S(V)]=j≥0∑​[Sj(V)]tn

Todd's formula

σt=∑j≥0σjtj \displaystyle{ \sigma_t = \sum_{j \ge 0} \sigma^j t^j }σt​=j≥0∑​σjtj

is just a distillation of this.

Can we understand it a bit more precisely? Yes! @Todd Trimble is using the fact that we don't need to separately consider each 2-rig R\mathsf{R}R. We can work 'universally' in the free 2-rig on one generator, called the 2-rig of Schur functors or sometimes kS‾\overline{k\mathsf{S}}kS or sometimes more charisimatically Schur\mathsf{Schur}Schur. The jth symmetric power of this generator is often simply called SjS^jSj, since it represents the operation of taking the jth symmetric power.

For any object VVV of any 2-rig, its jth symmetric power is called Sj(V)S^j(V)Sj(V). But we can also talk about SjS^jSj all by itself, waiting to act on some object of some 2-rig - and it's an object in Schur\mathsf{Schur}Schur.

The infinite coproduct

S≅⨁j≥0Sj \displaystyle{ S \cong \bigoplus_{j \ge 0} S^j } S≅j≥0⨁​Sj

is not an object of Schur\mathsf{Schur}Schur, since that 2-rig doesn't have infinite coproducts. But it's well-defined as an N\mathbb{N}N-graded Schur\mathsf{Schur}Schur-object! So, we can write

S≅⨁j≥0Sjtj∈Schur[[t]] \displaystyle{ S \cong \bigoplus_{j \ge 0} S^j t^j \in \mathsf{Schur}[[t]] }S≅j≥0⨁​Sjtj∈Schur[[t]]

where the tjt^jtj is just a formal notation that tells us what grade we're in.

More precisely: given any X∈Schur X \in \mathsf{Schur}X∈Schur we use XtjX t^jXtj to mean the N\mathbb{N}N-graded Schur\mathsf{Schur}Schur-object with XXX in the jth graded and zero everywhere else. Then given any N\mathbb{N}N-graded Schur\mathsf{Schur}Schur-object XXX, we have

X≅⨁j≥0Xjtj \displaystyle{ X \cong \bigoplus_{j \ge 0} X_j t^j } X≅j≥0⨁​Xj​tj

sending any object V∈RV\in RV∈R to its symmetric algebra S(V)S(V)S(V)

Yes, this was also discussed in the big Witt thread, which I was piggybacking off of. There was the additional comment that the symmetric algebra construction is left adjoint to the forgetful functor from commutative kkk-algebras to kkk-vector spaces, and being left adjoint, it preserves coproducts. The coproduct in the category of commutative kkk-algebras is given by tensor product ⊗k\otimes_k⊗k​. Hence

S(V⊕W)≅S(V)⊗S(W)S(V \oplus W) \cong S(V) \otimes S(W)S(V⊕W)≅S(V)⊗S(W)

and this is the origin of the statement of the "exponential law", which in decategorified form reads

σt(x+y)=σt(x)σt(y)\sigma_t(x + y) = \sigma_t(x) \sigma_t(y)σt​(x+y)=σt​(x)σt​(y)

when interpreted as a statement about lambda-rings.

I wonder if we can work the grading of the symmetric algebra into that statement about SSS being left adjoint to the forgetful functor from commutative algebras to vector spaces. I.e. can we use some high-powered formal wizardry to instantly see that SSS is a functor from vector spaces to graded commutative algebras (with the boring 'bosonic' symmetry on graded vector spaces)?

I mean it's obvious, but Freyd would want it to be obviously obvious.

There must be a left adjoint to the forgetful functor from graded commutative algebras to graded commutative vector spaces, and restricting this adjoint to graded commutative vector spaces that vanish outside grade zero we get the version of SSS that I'm talking about.

I think maybe you meant vanish at grade 000, not outside grade 000. If VVV sits in grade 000, then all the Sn(V)S^n(V)Sn(V) also sit in grade 000, but then their infinite coproduct might not exist as an object in the general 2-rig RRR.

The map R→R[[t]]\mathsf{R} \to \mathsf{R}[[t]]R→R[[t]] sends an object r∈Rr \in \mathsf{R}r∈R to its doppelganger in grade 111 (or in grade 222 if we are using the signed symmetry) and then applies the symmetric algebra construction, so that the copies Sn(r)S^n(r)Sn(r) get spread out along the grading.
But I think you're right that this could use a little tidying up.

Todd Trimble said:

I think maybe you meant vanish at grade 000, not outside grade 000

Whoops, I meant vanish outside grade 111. I wanted to think of the usual symmetric algebra of a vector space as a special case of the free commutative graded algebra on a graded vector space, so I'm including Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect in Vect[[t]]\mathsf{Vect}[[t]]Vect[[t]], but I should include it in grade 1, like you said.

Anyway, all this is the easy part. And similarly, categorifying the formula

λt=∑j≥0λjtj \displaystyle{ \lambda_t = \sum_{j \ge 0} \lambda^j t_j }λt​=j≥0∑​λjtj​

is easy if we work with N\mathbb{N}N-graded Schur functors. I was mainly trying to get our audience up to speed (if anyone is actually listening).

What we really want to discuss, I think, is how to handle the Adams operations and formulas like

ψt=∑j≥0ψjtj \displaystyle{ \psi_t = \sum_{j \ge 0} \psi^j t^j }ψt​=j≥0∑​ψjtj

which are not merely decategorifications of isomorphisms between N\mathbb{N}N-graded objects in 2-rigs.

Your Schur functors are modules for SSS, the symmetric monoidal category of finite sets and bijections under disjoint union, and E∞E_{\infty}E∞​ rings are modules for S\mathbb{S}S.

As Qiaochu Yuan tells us here,

SSS is the free symmetric monoidal ∞-category on a point, while S\mathbb{S}S is the free symmetric monoidal ∞-groupoid with inverses on a point,

While our friend S\mathsf{S}S is the free symmetric monoidal category on an object, and also the free symmetric monoidal ∞-category on a point, it happens to be a groupoid (the groupoid of finite sets, for anyone who just tuned in), so without damage we can think of it as a homotopy type, and then it's the space of finite subsets of points in R∞\mathbb{R}^\inftyR∞. I visualize such a subset as a swarm of gnats particles. Such a finite collection of particles in R∞\mathbb{R}^\inftyR∞ is the homotopy theorist's version of a natural number.

If we include antiparticles and let particles and antiparticles be created and annihilated in pairs, we get S\mathbb{S}S. A particle-antiparticle swarm is the homotopy theorist's version of an integer.

So yes, there's a very appealing map S→S\mathsf{S} \to \mathbb{S}S→S.

Motivated by Kapranov, the quest was for a form of 'spectral supergeometry' and we (largely Urs) got as far as wanting to look at E∞E_{\infty}E∞​ algebras over an even periodic ring spectrum as the spectral equivalent of Z/2\mathbb{Z}/2Z/2-grading.

Charles Rezk had also been looking at these in section 2 of The congruence criterion for power operations in Morava E-theory, (arXiv:0902.2499), a paper studying some higher analogue of a result for λ\lambdaλ-rings:

The purpose of this paper is to prove a congruence criterion for the algebraic theory of power operations acting on the homotopy of a K(n)K(n)K(n)-local commutative EEE-algebra spectrum... This criterion is best understood as being a higher chromatic analogue of Wilkerson’s congruence criterion for λ\lambdaλ-rings,

Wilkerson having characterized "the torsion free λ\lambdaλ-rings in terms of congruences on the Adams operations at all primes".

So we had a Z\mathbb{Z}Z (really S\mathbb{S}S)-graded thing looking for a further Z/2\mathbb{Z}/2Z/2 grading and having something to do with higher chromatic forms of properties concerning Adams operations on λ\lambdaλ-rings.

Ironically I'm making a bit of progress, not in this work with Todd, but in my conversations with James Dolan, who has noticed a really nice link between general formal group laws (which have a "height" connected to the chromatic hierarchy) and the Eisenstein series of elliptic curves (which give formal group laws of height one or two). This is surely understood by experts, but he likes to rediscover things on his own. Feynman said "I cannot understand what I do not invent", and James is like that.

As part of this, together with @Chris Grossack (they/them), we are having fun thinking about supersingular elliptic curves. These are the elliptic that give formal group laws of height two, for some reason I don't yet understand. But they also have lots of other interesting properties. By definition, a supersingular elliptic curve is an elliptic curve defined over a finite field whose endomorphism ring is surprisingly large, basically 4-dimensional instead of what one usually sees, 1-dimensional or 2-dimensional. Their Eisenstein series also have special properties... and it's the Eisenstein series that provide clues about the corresponding formal group laws!

James likes to use Mathematica to do lots of concrete calculations with examples - a great way to keep things real and observe surprising patterns that one couldn't easily guess from general principles. So for example we're studying a table of all supersingular elliptic curves over fields of characteristic ppp for p≤37p \le 37p≤37, and looking at the Eisenstein series of these elliptic curves, and noticing strange patterns....

Anyway, with enough work like that I might understand elliptic curves and their corresponding formal group laws well enough to get a good handle on topological modular forms, which is the next step up the chromatic hierarchy from K-theory. Are there something like Adams operations in tmf? I don't know. Luckily I'm having a lot of fun down here in the dirt!

Let me say a bit about how this might work.

First, some known stuff. A linear category is a Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect-enriched category, and it's Cauchy complete if it has all absolute colimits, i.e. it has biproducts and splittings of idempotents. There's a tensor product ⊠\boxtimes⊠ of Cauchy complete linear categories, discussed on page 15 here. A 2-rig is a
symmetric pseudomonoid with respect to the ⊠\boxtimes⊠ tensor product: in short, it's a symmetric monoidal Cauchy complete linear category. In Lemma 4.2 on page 24 we showed that if R\mathsf{R}R and S\mathsf{S}S are 2-rigs so is R⊠S\mathsf{R} \boxtimes \mathsf{S}R⊠S, and this actually the coproduct of R\mathsf{R}R and S\mathsf{S}S in the 2-category of 2-rigs.

Remember I'm writing Kb(R)K_b(\mathsf{R})Kb​(R) for the category of bounded Z\mathbb{Z}Z-graded chain complexes in the 2-rig R\mathsf{R}R. It's easy to see that this is a Cauchy complete linear category, but why is it a 2-rig?

(Btw, everything I say should also work for N\mathbb{N}N-graded chain complexes, and I'm only using Z\mathbb{Z}Z-graded ones because that's what people talking about derived categories seem to do.)

Let me write Kb\mathsf{K}_bKb​ for Kb(FinVect)K_b(\mathsf{FinVect})Kb​(FinVect). This should be a 2-rig with the familiar tensor product of chain complexes and the familiar symmetric monoidal structure where you introduce a minus sign when switching two elements of odd grade. I believe that for any 2-rig R\mathsf{R}R we have an equivalence of linear categories

Kb(R)≃Kb⊠R K_b(\mathsf{R}) \simeq \mathsf{K}_b \boxtimes \mathsf{R}Kb​(R)≃Kb​⊠R

This should be easy to check 'by hand'. This makes Kb(R)K_b(\mathsf{R})Kb​(R) into a 2-rig, since it's a tensor product of 2-rigs.

Now we have

Kb(Schur)≃Kb⊠SchurK_b(\mathsf{Schur}) \simeq \mathsf{K}_b \boxtimes \mathsf{Schur} Kb​(Schur)≃Kb​⊠Schur

and this should make it easier to see how we get a linear functor

Kb(Schur)⊠Kb(R)→Kb(R) K_b(\mathsf{Schur}) \boxtimes K_b(\mathsf{R}) \to K_b(\mathsf{R}) Kb​(Schur)⊠Kb​(R)→Kb​(R)

for any 2-rig R\mathsf{R}R.

We already know that Schur\mathsf{Schur}Schur acts on any 2-rig (as linear functors, not 2-rig maps), giving a linear functor

Schur⊠R→R \mathsf{Schur} \boxtimes \mathsf{R} \to \mathsf{R} Schur⊠R→R

We thus get a linear functor

Kb⊠Schur⊠R→Kb⊠R \mathsf{K}_b \boxtimes \mathsf{Schur} \boxtimes \mathsf{R} \to \mathsf{K}_b \boxtimes \mathsf{R} Kb​⊠Schur⊠R→Kb​⊠R

or in other words
